Expectation1: Attending children's school events and activities
Situation1: The school reports that the child was caught bullying a classmate, and the parent needs to respond
Expectation2: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation2: A routine audit is scheduled far ahead, leaving ample time to update documentation
Story: I stared at the email from my child’s school, my heart sinking as I read the words: “Your child was involved in a bullying incident today. We request your presence to discuss the matter.” I knew I had to be there for my child, to understand what happened, to show the school I took this seriously. But as I reached for my phone to call my manager, another notification popped up—a reminder about the upcoming safety audit at work. As the lead engineer, I was expected to ensure every document was flawless, every standard met. The audit was still weeks away, but I’d promised my team I’d review the new compliance checklist today, and they were waiting for my feedback. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing down on me: my child needed me as a parent, my team needed me as an engineer. I could feel the anxiety rising, torn between the urgent call of family and the steady, relentless demands of my profession.
